steps.content: The ğŸš€ rocket emoji primarily represents space. steps.content: The ğŸš€ emoji can refer to a fast increase. Rockets fly high at fast speeds, so some people use the ğŸš€ emoji to signify rapid growth. steps.content: The ğŸš€ emoji can signify success or ambition. Thereâ€™s an idiom that you have to â€œaim highâ€ to be successful, so many people use the ğŸš€ emoji to talk about their dreams and ambitions. steps.content: The ğŸš€ emoji can also symbolize speed and energy. When a rocket is launched, it propels through space at a high speed. So, many people use the ğŸš€ emoji to talk about sports. steps.content: The ğŸš€ emoji may indicate a startup or product launch. Just like a rocket is launched into space, the ğŸš€ emoji can represent the launch of a new company or product. [5] X Research source Use it in emails, newsletters, text blasts, or social media captions to create buzz for your business or workplace. â€œOnly 2 more days until our seltzers drop in stores ğŸš€â€ â€œThe most exciting beauty startup is launching this week ğŸš€â€ â€œSign up for our newsletter to get an early look at our newest product ğŸš€ğŸª–â€

steps.content: The ğŸš€ emoji can be used to refer to warfare. Some people use the ğŸš€ emoji to talk about war, missiles, or other weaponry. steps.content: The ğŸš€ emoji means you have to leave in slang. Think of the ğŸš€ emoji as another way of saying â€œ got to go â€ or â€œgot to blast.â€ [7] X Research source If youâ€™re in a rush or itâ€™s getting late, you can use it to quickly end the conversation. steps.title: The ğŸš€ emoji may symbolize a potent drug.
steps.content: The ğŸš€ emoji may symbolize a potent drug. In street slang, the ğŸš€ emoji can refer to the strength or potency of drugs. [8] X Research source This meaning is more likely in online chats between drug dealers and potential clients, which can happen on platforms like Snapchat, Instagram, and WhatsApp. The ğŸš€ emoji can also be used to describe the effects of drugs or alcohol. â€œI heard her dealer has ğŸš€ MDMA.â€ â€œI took 7 shots so I donâ€™t remember much from last night ğŸš€â€ â€œHe took something at the rave and was wired to the moon ğŸš€â€

steps.title: The ğŸš€ emojiâ€™s unicode is U+1F680.
steps.content: The ğŸš€ emojiâ€™s unicode is U+1F680. If you need to display the rocket emoji in your HTML code, type in â€œ&#x1F680.â€ [9] X Research source Some fonts, like Twemoji and EmojiOne, include a wide range of emojis you can use, as long as you include a reference to the font in your HTML code and use the corresponding character code. To copy and paste the ğŸš€ emoji on your computer, highlight the emoji, right-click the mouse or trackpad, and hit â€œCopy.â€ Then, right-click where you want to place the emoji and select â€œPaste.â€

steps.title: The ğŸš€ emoji was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
steps.content: The ğŸš€ emoji was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015. It was officially approved as part of Unicode 6.0 on October 11, 2010. [10] X Research source This was the first standardized version of Unicode, meaning brands like Google, Microsoft, Facebook, and Twitter could create their own versions of emojis (so they would appear even if a message was sent from a different operating system). [11] X Research source Unicode 6.0 is also the largest release of emojis to date, with 994 characters like emotions, hearts, animals, clothes, food, city images, clocks, and country flags.
